bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 22, 1879

div1.p: Reed hopes that his wife's health improves. He offers news of colleagues at Fort Apache and hopes for an assignment back east. He has received no letter from her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 22, 1879
div1.p:
As Señor Don Alberti
alias, “it shall be most excellent,” “ vala mañana al campo
Thomas à cavallo” (it is not necessary to trans-
late, I know) I cannot let the opportunity go
by of writing somewhat to the “feetest”; ittle
dal in the County yo. “How is mantee's ittle
teeter” looking this afternoon? As pretty and
neat as a little picture, I know- And, love
her precious heart, she knows how to look
just as pretty and graceful as any angel!
Husband looks forward with many happy
anticipations of joining his darling, Emilie,
wifie, “and expects her to meet him with the
brightest smile and the prettiest, rosiest lips,
and such a sweet kiss he expects to receive from
those cherry lips as will make him think
that he is ten years younger. “A kiss” did
I say? yes ten thousand times ten thousand
sweet kisses will husband demand, and
his pretty wife will not ever begrudge him one.
And how is papa's darling little Lawrence
too, this afternoon? For papa hasn't forgotten
his pretty boy! Does he like his new nurse
& go out every day into the fresh air and Sun-
shine? what does “bad daddie” think of his
colored “mamy” any way? Have you bought
him a pretty, nice carriage to ride him in,
my darling E.? And got plenty of new clothes
for our little son? Now, mother, don't you
go & let other children dress better than old
“didn't didn't day,” you hear? You know,
mother, that he is just as pretty as any of
them & he must be given every chance to
shine- But husband knows enough of his
loved Emilie & her good taste, to rest sat-
isfied that no child will look neater and
nicer than his & her darling little son-
Do you kiss him, my darling wife, forty
times every day for his own dear papa?
Does he never say anything about papa
or seem to miss him any? Don't let him
forget me, my precious E., but talk to him
about papa every day. By the way, dar-
ling, while I think of it, please don't al-
low him to break up his habit of being
put to sleep without any rocking or nur-
sing of any kind- If his old colored mother
begins to spoil him, stop her at once, my
lovely wife. I am so anxious to get a
letter, a long one, from you, darling, telling
me all about your arrival in Norfolk
and Murfreesboro, and what they all had
to say about yourself & Lawrence- Did
they think you were looking dreadfully
broken down in health? I do hope & daily
pray that my loved wife may grow strong
& get real well very soon -- and next after
her darling self & “bad daddies”, I pray & hope
that I may soon be relieved from Ari-
zona & ordered East- You can't imagine
my precious little piggie, how happy I am
when I think that you & Lawrence are
East & out of Arizona- I picture, my darlings
as enjoying themselves & this thought makes
me so happy & thankful! Of course, my house-
-keeping troubles are none at all now- I
am a member of the batchelor mess, and have
nothing to do but go down three times a day
and eat breakfast, lunch & dinner-
Shadwicks still remains as cook and does
up things in very nice style -- our mess num-
bers six, Stanton, Lassin, Mills, Gatewood,
McPherson & Reed -& we have a jolly, pleasant
time- Mr. Stanton & the other gentleman frequently
inquire after you, my darling, & also concerning
papa's boy. Mr Staples inquired of you, this
morning- They all wish to be remembered
kindly- I think I have forgotten poor little
Undie, thus far. She often asks of “Mittee” & says, “tell
Mittee that in a few days, I pec I'll have two
ittle tiney puppies”- Her little “tumuck” is gradually
expanding, day by day, and I think she will have
two sure enough. She says, “tell mittee & little mottee
that I often think of them & will telegraph
them as soon as my little boys arrive.” She sends
much love & a kiss to each of you. Little Susie
is quite well & when I asked her, a few days ago,
whether she wanted to see Miss Emilie & the baby,
she put on a broad grin & said “yeth”- she still
stays at the Hospital. It is now a quarter to three
o'clock, and I am invited to dine at Mrs. Compton's at 4 P.M.
As I didn't get the invitation till after eating my lunch,
I don't think I will be able to do justice to the sub-
ject. Give my very best love to mother, sister & all the others.
Be a darling little Emilie, wifie- Love papa's boy, to whom he
sends many kisses & oceans of love, a heap- & write often to your own darling
Mantee,

closer.seg:
PS. Papa's boy
must give Ma-
ma three good
kisses for papa
W. de A.
